text: <extra_id_0> Protein phosphatases 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> 2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are important in regulating cellular functions by controlling the phosphorylation state of their substrates .

In human monocytes , the inhibitors of these phosphatases , okadaic acid and calyculin A , were found to increase the mRNA accumulation and cytokine production of <extra_id_0> interleukin-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> interleukin-1 alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: The increased mRNA accumulation was found to be primarily because of the increase in the transcription rate of the interleukin-1 genes .

Stimulation of interleukin-1 gene transcription may be caused by the stimulation of transcription factor activities , including those of <extra_id_0> AP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , by these protein phosphatase inhibitors .
Okadaic acid increased the synthesis of the <extra_id_0> interleukin-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> precursor and mature forms and their secretion .

text: These results show that <extra_id_0> protein phosphatase 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> 2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibitors exert multiple effects on cytokine production in human monocytes and suggest that these two phosphatases play important roles in regulating interleukin-1 production .
